about.title: About Wulkan Kibo
about.intro: Bringing the rich flavors of Africa to kitchens around the world
about.ourStoryP1: "Wulkan Kibo" is a project where we show that African cuisine is not only about dishes, but also about history, traditions, and a way of thinking about the world. We teach cooking step by step, present interesting facts about ingredients and culture, while also talking about respect, diversity, and the fight against racism. Our content is aimed at people curious about the world, open to new flavors, and those who want to better understand other cultures. Through videos, recipes, and educational materials, we help discover something new, build greater awareness, and create a more welcoming community. We want everyone to be able to taste Africa in their kitchen and look at it from a new perspective.
about.ourMissionIntro: We believe that everyone should have access to authentic African recipes and the knowledge to prepare them with confidence. Our mission is to:
about.mission1: Preserve and share traditional African cooking techniques through video tutorials
about.mission2: Make African cuisine accessible to home cooks of all skill levels
about.mission3: Celebrate the diversity of culinary cultures across the African continent
about.mission4: Build a community of food lovers who appreciate African flavors
about.mission5: Provide clear, detailed instructions that honor authentic preparation
about.feature1Desc: Step-by-step video guides showing you exactly how to prepare each dish from start to finish.
about.feature2Desc: Comprehensive written instructions with ingredient lists, cooking times, and helpful tips.
about.feature3Desc: Learn about the history and cultural significance of each dish and cooking technique.
about.feature4Desc: Join a growing community of food enthusiasts sharing their experiences with African cooking.
about.whyNameP1: Kilimanjaro, known locally as "Kibo", rises as Africa's highest peak - a symbol of strength, beauty, and natural wonder. Like the mountain, African cuisine reaches great heights through its bold flavors, diverse ingredients, and honored traditions.
about.whyNameP2: "Wulkan" (volcano) represents the passion and energy that goes into every dish - the fire that transforms raw ingredients into unforgettable meals shared with family and friends.
about.teamSubtitle: Wulkan Kibo is brought to life by a passionate team dedicated to sharing the beauty of African cuisine with the world.
about.teamJarodBio: What motivated me to create this project was the desire to show other people my culture and food. I think what I will enjoy most is the opportunity to cook, work in a team, and start a new adventure.
about.teamJosiahBio: I'm responsible for the technical side of the project — from managing the website to recording video materials. I specialize in IT matters and film equipment. I joined Wulkan Kibo because I see huge potential in this project… and I simply love food.
about.teamIgaBio: Since childhood, I've loved exploring new cultures, especially when it comes to flavors from different parts of the world. I'm very determined to learn about traditional cuisine and am eager to develop my skills in this direction. I think this can be a wonderful adventure that will allow everyone to discover new possibilities.
about.teamNinaBio: I'm interested in learning about new cultures and flavors from different corners of the world. I would like to learn more about African cuisine, its traditions and spices. I enjoy developing my culinary skills. That's why creating a team and participating in the Wulkan Kibo project was a great idea.
about.teamRomanBio: I'm a person curious about new flavors and culinary experiences. I also really enjoy experimenting with new projects like Wulkan Kibo. And I hope that together we will cook many delicious dishes.
about.teamIgnacyBio: On a daily basis, I love cooking and trying various new recipes. I have great hope that during the Wulkan Kibo project I will learn more about African cuisine and its culture. Apart from culinary interests, I'm very interested in tennis.
about.joinP1: Whether you're discovering African cuisine for the first time or looking to perfect family recipes, Wulkan Kibo is here to guide you. We're constantly adding new recipes, tips, and resources to help you master the art of African cooking.
about.joinP2: Share your culinary adventures with us using
about.joinP2b: on social media. We love seeing our recipes come to life in your kitchens around the world!
about.ctaDesc: Join thousands learning authentic African cuisine

recipes.jollofDescription: Learn to make authentic African Jollof Rice with this step-by-step video tutorial. Perfect one-pot meal with rich tomato sauce and aromatic spices.
recipes.jollofIngredient15: Salt and black pepper to taste
recipes.jollofStep1: Rinse the rice thoroughly under cold water until the water runs clear. Drain and set aside.
recipes.jollofStep2: Heat the vegetable oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add the diced onion and cook until soft and translucent, about 5 minutes.
recipes.jollofStep3: Add the minced garlic and cook for 1 minute until fragrant, stirring constantly to avoid burning.
recipes.jollofStep4: Stir in the tomato paste and cook for 2–3 minutes, stirring frequently to deepen the flavor.
recipes.jollofStep5: Add the crushed tomatoes, thyme, curry powder, paprika, and cayenne. Mix well and simmer for 5 minutes to meld the flavors.
recipes.jollofStep6: Pour in the stock, add bay leaves and the scotch bonnet (use whole for milder heat). Bring the mixture to a boil.
recipes.jollofStep7: Add the rinsed rice and diced bell peppers. Stir well to distribute evenly. Season with salt and black pepper to taste.
recipes.jollofStep8: Reduce heat to low, cover tightly, and cook for 25–30 minutes without stirring. The rice should be tender and the liquid absorbed.
recipes.jollofStep9: Remove from heat and rest covered for 5 minutes. Fluff gently with a fork, remove bay leaves and scotch bonnet. Garnish with fresh parsley and serve hot.
recipes.jollofVideoDesc: Watch how we prepare this dish step by step
recipes.peanutIngredient6: 3/4 cup natural peanut butter (smooth or chunky)
recipes.peanutIngredient8: 2 large sweet potatoes, peeled and cubed (1-inch pieces)
recipes.peanutIngredient12: 4 cups fresh spinach or kale, roughly chopped
recipes.peanutIngredient13: Salt and black pepper to taste
recipes.peanutStep1: Sauté aromatics: Heat vegetable oil in a large pot or Dutch oven over medium heat. Add diced onion and cook until softened and translucent, about 5 minutes.
recipes.peanutStep2: Add garlic and ginger: Add minced garlic and grated ginger. Cook for 1 minute, stirring constantly, until fragrant.
recipes.peanutStep3: Build flavor base: Stir in diced tomatoes with their juices, cumin, coriander, and cayenne pepper. Cook for 3 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld.
recipes.peanutStep4: Create peanut sauce: Add peanut butter and vegetable broth to the pot. Whisk vigorously until the peanut butter is fully incorporated and the mixture is smooth and creamy.
recipes.peanutStep5: Cook sweet potatoes: Add cubed sweet potatoes to the stew. Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce heat to medium-low and simmer uncovered for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until sweet potatoes are tender when pierced with a fork.
recipes.peanutStep6: Add greens: Stir in fresh spinach or kale and cook for 2-3 minutes until wilted. Season with salt and black pepper to taste.
recipes.peanutStep7: Serve: Ladle hot stew into bowls. Garnish with chopped peanuts and fresh cilantro. Serve with cooked rice, quinoa, or crusty bread.
recipes.plantainIngredient1: 4 ripe plantains (yellow with black spots for best sweetness)
recipes.plantainIngredient2: 2 tablespoons fresh ginger, peeled and grated
recipes.plantainIngredient4: 1 teaspoon cayenne pepper (adjust according to spice preference)
recipes.plantainIngredient9: Vegetable oil for deep frying (about 3-4 cups)
recipes.plantainStep1: Prepare plantains: Peel ripe plantains. Cut them into bite-sized cubes (about 1 inch) or diagonal slices. Pieces should be uniform for even cooking.
recipes.plantainStep2: Make spice mixture: In a large bowl, combine grated ginger, finely chopped onion, cayenne pepper, paprika, ground cloves, salt, and black pepper. Mix well to create an aromatic spice blend.
recipes.plantainStep3: Marinate plantains: Add cut plantain pieces to the spice mixture. Toss gently with your hands or a spoon to coat each piece evenly with the spices. Let marinate for 10 minutes to absorb the flavors.
recipes.plantainStep4: Heat oil: Pour vegetable oil into a deep frying pan, skillet, or pot until it's about 2 inches deep. Heat over medium-high heat to 350°F (175°C). Test readiness by dropping in a small piece of plantain - it should immediately sizzle.
recipes.plantainStep5: Fry in batches: Carefully add plantain pieces to the hot oil in batches, making sure not to overcrowd the pan. Fry for 3-4 minutes per side, turning occasionally, until golden brown and crispy on the edges.
recipes.plantainStep6: Drain and serve: Remove fried plantains with a slotted spoon and transfer to a plate lined with paper towels to drain excess oil. Serve immediately while hot and crispy. Enjoy as a snack or side dish!
recipes.jollofTip1: Rice choice: Parboiled rice works best as it stays fluffy and doesn't become mushy.
recipes.jollofTip2: Spice level: Adjust cayenne pepper and scotch bonnet to your preference. Remove scotch bonnet before serving if you left it whole.
recipes.jollofTip3: Smoky flavor: For authentic party jollof, let the bottom lightly burn to achieve a smoky, crispy layer called "socarrat".
recipes.jollofTip4: Protein additions: Serve with grilled chicken, beef, or fish for a complete meal.
recipes.jollofTip5: Storage: Store leftovers in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 4 days. Reheat gently with a splash of water.
recipes.peanutTip1: Peanut butter: Use natural peanut butter without added sugar for authentic flavor. Almond butter can be a substitute for those with nut allergies.
recipes.peanutTip2: Protein boost: Add chickpeas, black-eyed peas, or cubed tofu for extra protein.
recipes.peanutTip3: Consistency: If stew is too thick, add more broth. If too thin, simmer uncovered to reduce.
recipes.peanutTip4: Make ahead: This stew tastes even better the next day. Store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days or freeze for up to 3 months.
recipes.peanutTip5: Spice level: Adjust cayenne pepper to your preference. Add a squeeze of lime juice for freshness.
recipes.plantainTip1: Plantain ripeness: Use ripe plantains with yellow skin and black spots for the perfect balance of sweetness. Avoid green plantains - they are too starchy for this recipe.
recipes.plantainTip2: Oil temperature: Maintaining the proper oil temperature (175°C) is crucial. Too hot and they'll burn on the outside while remaining raw inside; too cool and they'll absorb too much oil.
recipes.plantainTip3: Spice variations: Adjust cayenne pepper based on your heat tolerance. Some recipes include nutmeg or anise for additional flavor complexity.
recipes.plantainTip4: Serving suggestions: Kelewele is traditionally served as a snack with peanuts or as a side dish to grilled fish or chicken. Also great for breakfast!
recipes.plantainTip5: Storage: Best enjoyed fresh, but leftovers can be stored in the refrigerator for 2 days and reheated in the oven at 175°C for 10 minutes to restore crispiness.
